item.title: Blackberry
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

I got my curve for free with a plan renewal, but I would never buy one if I had to get a new phone, mainly because most applications are shit compared to iPhone and Android ones. But the thing I do love about them is the comfortable keyboard, and the fact that I absolutely despise touch-screen keyboards. Sure BBM is cool, but I see no difference in it as opposed to any other instant messaging system. It’s only good since just about everyone who has a Blackberry is completely hooked to it and respond to a message immediately.

However, after seeing phones like the HTC EVO and the Droid X, I’d say Android is definitely the way to go.

Read full topic

item.title: Blackberry
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Newty:

My curve gets the job done. Posting from it right now actually.

I’m sure it does. They function perfectly fine. What I’m saying is other mobile operating systems like Android and iOS do the job better for the general usage, unless you prefer the keyboards on blackberry phones and are invested into BBM.

Blackberry has fantastic security and enterprise features, the bullets points for such features are being filled by Google and Apple for enterprise, like OTA app distribution, remote wipe, push calendar, email, contacts and other central management features - but RIM go further and have their own private infrastructure to ensure security for all different components that no one else is really doing.

That is why they’ll remain popular, because those large companies will buy them in buik and distribute them among employees and that is yet another area where RIM do best, distribution of the actual phones.

Read full topic

item.title: Blackberry
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Because they’re best for enterprise, they have the best security features and tools. For a general user, the operating system is far behind Android and iOS.

I’m not sure why people who don’t require those enterprise features use them, the keyboards? Blackberry messenger? I don’t know.
